On 7/14/05, lars_v_hansen <lvh@...> wrote:
> Hi Everyone
> 
> My na=
me is Lars and I am a student at Department of Computer Science,
> Universi=
ty of Aarhus, Denmark. I am writing my Master Thesis with my
> good friend =
Mathias who is also a student here ;-). As you probably
> already noticed t=
his thesis is about poker (Texas Hold'em) and GAs.

Hi Lars...welcome to th=
e group. :)  Yes, we are very interested in
applying neuroevolution to Poke=
r in general and Texas Hold 'Em in
particular.  It's nice to hear you're wo=
rking on this problem, and
that you're already familiar with the work of th=
e Alberta group.
 
> We just recently discovered NEAT (sadly :-() 


When i=
s your thesis due? ;)

Before I comment on the rest of your mail, I have a =
few questions:

1) You don't say how well your evolved networks perform...h=
ow are you
evaluating the performance of your resulting networks?  Are you
=
playing them on the Poki server?

2) Is the domain limit/pot limit/no limit=
?  Maybe you mentioned this
and I missed it, but it's a pretty big deal.  I=
 think it would be much
more difficult to gauge fitness as the amount to be=
 able to bet in a
single turn increases.  Limit is probably the least noisy=
 of the three
variations.

3) Do your networks use recurrent connections?

=
4) So do your networks always play 10 opponents?  If players are
eliminated=
 at a table (they run out of money), do the networks play
9-way hands?  Do =
the winners eventually play heads up?

> and yesterday we finished
> a new =
player based on jNEAT. The player ANN takes the following
> inputs:
> 
> 1 =
pot / bet

This seems fine.

> 1 position

Is this relative or absolute?  I=
f this input is just an integer value
between 0 and 9 that may not be as us=
eful as knowing it's distance to
the button each hand.

> 9 player actions =
this round

So all the actions are taken and then input to the network on i=
ts turn?  

> 9 player passive / aggressive index
> 9 player tight / loose =
index

How are you getting these values?  Are you using other networks for
=
opponent modeling, as Billings et al are doing?

> 2 suit count (4 or 5 siu=
ted cards)
> 2 connector count (4 or 5 connected cards)
> 4 card associatio=
ns (pair, two pairs, three of a kind, four of a kind)

Well, the problem I =
see with this representation right off the bat is
that there is no informat=
ion about the order/strength of the cards,
unless I'm not understanding.

W=
ould the network receive the same input for a pair of jacks as for a
pair o=
f 2's?  If so, the representation is seriously flawed.

Also, connectivity =
is important, but again rank is also important. 
A/2/3/4 is much worse than=
 8/9/10/J not only because it's lower but
because the latter is open-ended =
(a straight can be made with a 7 or
Q, while for the first one a straight c=
an only be made with a 5).

Philip and I have talked over the representatio=
n of Hold Em a bit.  I
don't have any easy answers, but I do think you need=
 at least one
input for the strength of your best combination.  So an input=
 for
pairs might tell the network it has a pair, and another input would
sc=
ale between 0 and 1 to indicate the strength (and you might want to
skew th=
is toward higher pairs).

> 2 hole cards in use ( are we using 1 or 2 hole =
cards in our hand?)
> 3 game stage (FLOP/TURN/RIVER)

These seem all right,=
 though possibly superflous.  Others may have thoughts.

> The outputs from=
 the ANN are straight forward:
> 3 neurons:
> FOLD | CALL | BET/RAISE

Yep.=
..sounds good. 

> The 50 players play against each other and a pot-odds-pl=
ayer
> (PO-player) - five of each at each table. They play 600 hands but no=
t
> at one table only - we mix them between the tables five times such
> th=
at they get to meet different individuals from the entire
> population.

Ho=
w often do you switch them?  It often takes a while for someone to
get a re=
ad on another player, and in this case they are playing full
tables.  If th=
e individual networks are having to assess the
tightness/looseness aggressi=
veness/passiveness of the players at their
table, this is a big burden on t=
he network, and if they are switching
opponents every 10 hands or so, it is=
 even more difficult.

> The reason we have the PO-players at each table is=
 for the players to
> be forced to learn faster and play tighter from the v=
ery beginning.

Yes, this makes sense.  And personally I would not remove t=
his player
from your evolutionary runs.  It makes sense to have a hand-code=
d
standard in among the other players as a baseline.  It's performance
acro=
ss generations should give you a decent idea of how your algorithm
is progr=
essing.

> A major concern is the fitness: We have talked about it for hour=
s and
> days but we always come back to the cash of the player. If we canno=
t
> apply expert knowledge - we cannot think of anything else than the
> am=
ount earned after x hands.

Well, that is the standard of fitness for real =
Poker players, isn't it? :)

I would think this would make the most sense a=
s the primary fitness
value.  Another alternative would be to simply play a=
n elimination
tournament and then assign fitness based on the place each ne=
twork
finished.  It depends on whether you want to evolve networks geared
m=
ore toward tournament play or come-and-go style Poker.

> 1) Is it possible=
 to achieve results with a 45->N->3 ANN in NEAT?

I wouldn't see why not.  =
Have you achieved any results?  I think you
could reduce your input space f=
or opponent actions, especially since
in cases where the network is playing=
 heads up, 24 of your inputs
aren't even going to be used each hand.

> 2) =
Any general comments regarding the population size for the above
> ANN?

I =
would think the general consensus would be that large populations
are bette=
r for difficult problems, and in the case of NEAT tolerate
higher mutation =
rates and more diversity.  But it kind of depends on
your computational res=
ources, doesn't it?  How long does a run with
600 individuals take?

Also, =
you mention Fogel and his evolved Checkers player.  Those runs
only had a p=
opulation of 30.

> 3) Any parameters we should put in a particular favoura=
ble setting?

Parameters like mutation rates and speciation variables seem =
pretty
idiosyncratic to me.  Again, if it's a large population, it's more
t=
olerant to higher mutation rates and greater speciation, but I do
think the=
re's a certain amount of hand tuning of these parameters that
you just can'=
t get around.

Anyway, it's nice to hear someone working on this.  We're de=
finitely
interested in hearing more.

Derek
